entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 10:43PM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
At 1043 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking line of strong thunderstorms along a line from 5 miles northeast of Hilton Head Airport to near St. Catherines Island, moving east at 30 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Hilton Head Island, Bluffton, Tybee Island, Fort Pulaski National Monument, Wilmington Island, Midtown Savannah, Downtown Savannah, Windsor Forest, Coffee Bluff and Montgomery.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 8:40PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
At 840 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking an area of thunderstorms moving across eastern Idaho, gradually moving into parts of western Wyoming.
HAZARD...Showers and thunderstorms are expected to move into portions of Teton and Park Counties through the next several hours. Brief periods of heavy rainfall, along with lightning will be possible, as well as gusty winds of 30 to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects. Motorists should be alert for sudden, strong crosswinds and poor visibility in heavy downpours.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yellowstone National Park; Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Jackson Hole

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 10:38PM EDT until August 19 at 12:45AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
FFWPHI
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southeastern Morris County in northern New Jersey... Northeastern Somerset County in northern New Jersey...
* Until 1245 AM EDT.
* At 1038 PM EDT, emergency management reported thunderstorms producing heavy rain with flooding around Morristown, with more rain coming into the warned area. Between 2.5 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch is possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Emergency management reported.
IMPACT...Flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets, and underpasses as well as other drainage and low lying areas.
* Some locations that may experience flash flooding include... Morristown, Somerville, Bridgewater, Madison, Middlesex, Florham Park, East Hanover, Bound Brook, Manville, Chatham, Morris Plains and Mendham.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 287 in New Jersey between mile markers 11 and 40. Interstate 78 in New Jersey between mile markers 30 and 42. Interstate 80 in New Jersey between mile markers 46 and 48.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 18 at 10:36PM EDT until August 19 at 1:45AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast New York, including the following counties, Nassau and Suffolk.
* WHEN...Until 145 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1036 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Up to 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Islip, Brentwood, Centereach, Deer Park, Lindenhurst, Medford, Hauppauge, Ronkonkoma, Babylon, Middle Island, Wading River, Coram, Holbrook, Bay Shore, Sayville, Farmingville, Rocky Point, Amityville, Calverton and Yaphank. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 18 at 9:13PM EDT until August 18 at 11:15PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
At 913 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area as additional showers and thunderstorms continue to move into the area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Baltimore... Pikesville... Middle River... Cockeysville... Dundalk... Towson... Catonsville... Essex... Woodlawn... Parkville... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.

At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County. At 22.0 feet, River Run Road at 29th loop floods in Suwannee County. Santa Fe Road in Columbia County is inaccessible. At 23.0 feet, Homes are inaccessible along River Run Road in Suwannee County west of 33rd Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 21.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 18.9 feet Sunday, August 25. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 18 at 8:03PM EDT until August 19 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 5 to 8 feet in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...East Carteret County, and Ocracoke Island and Hatteras Island.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Monday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 10 AM EDT Monday. For the High Surf Advisory, until 10 AM EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront may experience shallow flooding. Vulnerable dune structures along Ocracoke and Hatteras Islands will be most susceptible to impacts from ocean overwash. Portions of NC-12 may be impacted, especially around times of high tide. The next high tide is around 8 AM Monday morning. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion expected. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 1:30 PM Monday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Carteret; Ocracoke Island; Hatteras Island

* WHEN...Until 4 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Localized beach erosion may occur. Items along the beach may wash away.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...West to northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph will move across the Chukchi Coast and into Kotzebue Sound late Sunday afternoon along the Chukchi Coast, and Sunday evening across Kotzebue Sound. The highest winds and seas are diminishing Monday morning. Water levels are expected to be 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tideline during the peak of the event.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 18 at 6:02PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
AQAFWD
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Monday, August 19, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Monday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)
Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)
EPA Air Now (www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)
Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)
North Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality (www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wise; Denton; Collin; Hunt; Parker; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Kaufman; Hood; Johnson; Ellis; Henderson

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued August 18 at 1:28PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
ESFAFG
- Rainfall over the last few days of 1.5 to 2.5 inches in the Western Brooks Range, and specifically the Upper Kobuk Valley Basin, will result in rapid river rises.
- Expect rapid rises along smaller rivers and streams draining the Western Brooks Range through the weekend. Runoff will also cause the Kobuk River to rise through next week, with the river cresting around 56 feet at Kiana, which is below bankfull.
- http://www.weather.gov/aprfc

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 18 at 1:09PM AKDT until August 20 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Central Brooks Range rivers and streams, including the following areas, South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range and Upper Koyukuk Valley. This includes the cities of Wiseman, Coldfoot, Chandalar Dot Camp, Iniakuk Lake, The Dalton Highway From Mp 165 To Mp 232, Allakaket, Bettles, Evansville, Alatna, Gobblers Knob, Prospect Creek, Finger Mountain, The Yukon River Bridge, And The Dalton Highway From Mp 39 To Mp 164.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - 2-3 inches of rain over past two days along with another 1-2 inches during the next 12 hours will cause rapid increases in stream levels. Tributaries to the Koyukuk River could reach bankfull levels by Sunday evening or Monday morning.
The Koyukuk River at Bettles and Allakaket will rise significantly over the next 24 hours and crest late Monday or Tuesday. River levels at Bettles and Allakaket are currently forecast to remain below flood stage. The Koyukuk River at Hughes is expected to crest Wednesday below flood stage.
IMPACTS: Expect rapid water level increases over next 24 hours on rivers and streams in the Koyukuk River basin. Minor overbank flooding of some Koyukuk River tributaries is possible.
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Dalton Highway Summits

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 11:41AM AKDT until August 19 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Winds from a coastal storm will cause water to backup on the Kuskokwim River and surrounding low lying areas.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by high winds backing up flow along the lower Kuskokwim River and Kuskokwim Delta is expected.
* WHERE...Along the Kuskokwim River, related tributaries and low lying areas including: Akiak, Bethel and several other smaller communities downstream to the Delta.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Residents reported flooding and rapid bank erosion during Friday and Saturday's high tide at Akiak, Napakiak, Kasigluk, and Tuntutuliak. At Napakiak, residents reported high water threatening community infrastructures, from Friday and Saturday's high tide, inundating most low spots in the village, including the the road to the dump. Water levels are reported to be higher than during breakup flooding this past May. Residents in Kasigluk reported water was encroaching on low lying residences, with water levels similar to those seen during this year's breakup. In Tuntutuliak, residents are reporting high water in the village over the past few days.
Based on tidal and storm surge forecasts, river levels are expected to be highest during Sunday's high tide, with water levels at Bethel, along Brown's Slough, approaching the flood stage of 8.5 feet by Sunday afternoon.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1112 AM AKDT, a strong storm system has tracked northward across the Bering Sea towards Norton Sound, just to the north of the Y-K Delta as of late Sunday morning. Strong southwesterly winds, and associated storm surge, continue to block flow along the Kuskokwim River. High tide on Sunday will correspond closely to very high water levels along the lower Kuskokwim, causing inundation of homes and infrastructure, along with rapid bank erosion.
- For Kuskokwim River at Bethel: At 11:00am the stage was 5.07 feet at low tide. Flood Stage is 8.5 feet.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKDT MONDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 18 at 11:41AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A series of low pressure systems will impact the West Coast with strong winds, rain, and potential coastal flooding.
The first and weakest of these Bering storms is moving through the Bering Strait today into tonight, bringing large breaking waves and elevated water levels along the West Coast through Monday afternoon. Conditions are expected to improve Monday afternoon. For the latest details on this storm, please see current High Surf Advisories.
The second and stronger low, the remnants of Typhoon Ampil, will move north and east out of the northern Pacific into the southern Bering Sea Monday into Tuesday, into the central Bering Sea Tuesday night, and through the Bering Strait Wednesday. This track will bring a long fetch of strong and gusty southwesterly winds to areas south of the Bering Strait Tuesday into Wednesday. This dynamic fetch will enhance the potential of coastal flooding along the West Coast south of the Bering Strait Wednesday into Thursday. Weather models vary on timing and exact track of this storm at this time. The track of this low will greatly affect which areas see the strongest winds and highest water levels. We will continue to closely monitor this storm.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast

cap:parameter.value: A Series of Strong Coastal Storms Expected through Mid-Week

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 1:45PM EDT until August 19 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County between State Road 53 and the Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 and 262. All of the flooding is due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby. Expect new flooded areas as water continues to slowly move to the south and east across Madison County.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida, including the following county, Madison.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 139 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist into next week due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby around August 5. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee and Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:30PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category.
* WHERE...North central and northeastern Minnesota.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening.. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday. The air quality may temporarily improve during the afternoon hours before degrading again overnight. Areas near Lake Superior may also experience smoke trapped in marine fog, similar to what occured earlier this week. Because of this air quality may be worse immediately surrounding Lake Superior compared to areas inland.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 12:16PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...in effect until noon PDT Monday.
This air quality advisory covers Lake and northern Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in eastern Douglas and Jackson County through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT MONDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 10:53AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT MONDAY.
A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
For additional information...please visit the Web site at http://www.oregon.gov/DEQ
